to produce Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP composites; (b–d) SEM images of (b) ZIF-67, (c) Co/NCP, and (d) Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP; (e) TEM image of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP; (f) HRTEM images of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP; (g) high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image and EDX elemental maps of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP. Fig. 2 (a) XRD pattern, (b) Raman spectra, and (c) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP; (d–f) XPS spectra of (d) Co 2p, (e) Mo 3d, and (f) Se 3d; (g) TDOS and (h) PDOS of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP; (i) electron gain/loss of Mo and Co as calculated by Bader charge analysis for Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP. Fig. 3 (a) Optical images of the Li2S6 solutions containing the same amounts of the different host materials after 6 h of adsorption; (b–d) high-resolution (b) Co 2p, (c) Mo 3d, and (d) Se 3d XPS spectra of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP before and after Li2S6 adsortion; (e) models used to determine the binding energy of Li2S6 on the surface of the different host materials; (f) adsorption energy of the different sulfur species on the surface of the different catalysts; (g) S–S and Li–S bond lengths on the surface of the different catalysts. Fig. 4 (a) CV profiles of symmetric cells at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1; (b) EIS spectra of the symmetric cell; (c) potentiostatic discharge curves for the nucleation kinetics of Li2S at 2.05 V; (d) LSV polarization curves and (e) Tafel plots of fresh LSBs; (f) Gibbs free energy profiles and optimized adsorption model of sulfur species on the surface of the three catalysts; (g) p orbital PDOS of S in Li2S4 adsorbed on the surface of the different catalysts. Fig. 5 (a) GCD curves of various cathodes at a current rate of 0.1 C; (b) polarization voltage ( Δ E) and capacity ratio (Q2/Q1) of the electrodes; (c) GCD profiles of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S at a current density of 0.1–3 C; (d, e) comparative rate performance of the different electrode materials; (f) CV curves for the various electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1; (g) peak and onset potentials for the different electrodes; (h) CV curves of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode at various scan rates; (i) CV peak (C1) current versus the square root of the scan rate; (j) Li+ diffusion coefficient from A, C1, and C2 peaks; (k) GITT voltage profiles of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode at 0.1 C; (l) internal resistances of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode relative to the normalized discharge-charge time. Fig. 6 (a) Cycle performances of LSB with different cathodes at 0.5 C; (b, c) EIS profiles of the cells before and after 200 cycles; (d) long cyclic performances at 1 C; (e) cycling performances and (f) charge and discharge curves of high sulfur loading cells with different electrolyte amounts at 0.2 C; (g) digital photographs of a red LED sign powered by two Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S Li-S coin cells; (h) scheme of the reaction mechanism, together with the side and top views of the heterostructure atomic arrangement and electron transfer process. Graphical abstract The Co0.85Se-MoSe2 heterostructure significantly enhances electron transfer efficiency and accelerates the redox kinetics of polysulfides in lithium-sulfur batteries, thereby achieving high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are a promising candidate for next-generation energy storage solutions. However, challenges such as the shuttling effect and sluggish Li-S reaction kinetics of lithium polysulfides hinder their practical application. In this work, we present a mixed-phase heterostructure comprising Co0.85Se and MoSe2, supported on nitrogen-doped carbon polyhedrons (NCP), as an effective sulfur host in the LSB cathode. Through a combination of theoretical calculations and experimental validation, we demonstrate that the Co0.85Se-MoSe2 heterointerface significantly enhances electron transfer efficiency, thereby boosting the overall reaction kinetics of the sulfur cathode. As a result, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes exhibit initial specific capacities exceeding 1500 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and retain 666 mAh g−1 at 3 C, with a capacity fade rate of 0.044% per cycle over 500 cycles at 1.0 C. Notably, even at a high sulfur loading of 3 mg cm−2 and a reduced electrolyte volume of 6.7 μL mgS −1, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes maintain a capacity of 432 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C. Keywords Heterostructure interface Lithium-sulfur battery Lithium polysulfides Transition metal selenide Electron transfer 1 Introduction Sulfur (S) cathodes have great potential in energy storage solutions for both mobile and stationary applications, owing to their potential for low cost, environmental friendliness, high energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), and specific capacity (1675 mAh g−1) [1–3]. However, the practical deployment of batteries based on S cathodes faces significant challenges, including the electrical insulating properties of the final charge and discharge products, the polysulfide shuttle effect caused by the dissolution of the intermediate cathode reaction products in the electrolyte, and the slow S redox reaction kinetics [4–7]. These issues result in low S utilization ratios, low charging and discharging rates, and rapid capacity fading. To address these limitations, various strategies have been proposed, including the development of catalytic S hosts and the engineering of functional separators and binders able to trap the polysulfides and accelerate their conversion [8,9]. The incorporation of small amounts of transition metal compounds has been proven to be particularly effective in accelerating sulfur redox reactions. Among transition metal dichalcogenides, NiAs-type materials such as CoSe and NiS stand out due to their unique hexagonal close-packed structures and metallic or semi-metallic properties, which provide high electrical conductivity for the enhanced electron transport and transfer [10]. For instance, Wen et al. synthesized a Co/CoSe junction derived from zeolitic imidazole framework (ZIF), which was reported to effectively catalyze polysulfide conversion [11]. However, the crystal structure of NiAs-type catalysts limits the exposure of most active sites, resulting in suboptimal polysulfide adsorption and catalytic performance. In contrast, layered transition metal dichalcogenides, such as MoS2 and MoSe2, also possess hexagonal crystal structures but with trigonal prismatic coordination and are typically semiconductors. Particularly, MoSe2-based catalysts have shown great promise due to their strong polysulfide adsorption capacity and electrocatalytic activity. For example, Xia et al. successfully designed a MoC-MoSe2 heterostructure through the in situ selenization of MoC, demonstrating that the internal electric field formed at the heterointerface facilitates electron transfer, thereby promoting polysulfide conversion [12]. Nevertheless, pure MoSe2 nanomaterials inevitably suffer from undesirable aggregation due to their high surface energy, leading to a significant reduction in surface area and active sites [13]. Additionally, their 2H phase exhibits limited active site density due to the inert nature of the (002) plane [14,15]. Moreover, the conductivity of MoSe2 materials still needs improvement for practical applications in high-rate rechargeable batteries. Although strategies such as strain engineering can be employed to modulate the d-band center of MoS2 and enhance catalytic activity [16], the overall performance of 2H-phase transition metal dichalcogenides remains constrained. To address the limitations of single-phase compounds, combining multiple chalcogenides allows leveraging the strengths of each component to enhance electronic conductivity, accelerate reaction kinetics, and improve polysulfide adsorption. In this study, we synthesized Co0.85Se/MoSe2 heterostructured particles supported on nitrogen-doped carbon polyhedrons (NCP) to create a catalytic composite (Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP). We further demonstrate these composites providing exceptional specific capacity, cycling stability, and rate capability as a sulfur host for Li-S batteries (LSBs). The superior performance arises from the synergistic interaction between the NiAs-type Co0.85Se structure and the 2H MoSe2 phase within the heterojunction. This design enhances catalytic efficiency and charge transfer dynamics, even under challenging conditions of high sulfur loading and dilute electrolytes. These results underscore the potential of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP composites as advanced materials for next-generation LSBs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis 2.1.1 Chemicals Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (analytical reagent, AR, Co (NO3)2·6H2O), 2-methylimidazole (AR, C4H6N2), Sulfur (≥99.0%, S), lithium sulfide (99.98%, Li2S), and phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (AR, 12MoO3·H3PO4·xH2O) were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. Selenium (99.5%, Se), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP), 1,3-dioxolane (DOL), and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) were purchased from Fisher. All chemicals were used as received, without further processing. Deionized water was used for all the water-based experiments. 2.1.2 Synthesis of ZIF-67 and Co/NCP 2.2 g Co (NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 125 mL methanol to form solution A. 1.64 g of 2-methylimidazole was dissolved in 125 mL methanol solution to form solution B. Then solution B was quickly added to solution A under rapid stirring and stirred for 30 min. The obtained mixture was aged for 24 h. The resulting powder was collected by centrifugation, washed with methanol three times, and dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 12 h to obtain cobalt-based ZIF-67. Co nanoparticles confined in N-doped carbon polyhedrons (Co/NCP) were synthesized by calcining the as-prepared ZIF-67 under an Ar atmosphere at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1 and the temperature was raised to 600 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 and held for 2 h. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Co/NCP/PMo12 The Co/NCP (300 mg) were homogeneously dispersed in 60 mL of deionized water via ultrasonication for 1.5 h. Subsequently, 365 mg of phosphomolybdic acid (PMo12) was added to the solution and blended for 1 h. The resultant dispersion was transferred into a 100 mL of Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 10 h. After cooling, the obtained precipitate was rinsed with deionized water and ethanol three times and then dried at 70 °C overnight. 2.1.4 Synthesis of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP The dried Co/NCP/PMo12 and Se powders with a weight ratio of 1:3 were placed into two separate porcelain boats and annealed under a reducing atmosphere of Ar/H2 (95/5 by volume) at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1. The temperature was increased to 600 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C min−1 and maintained for 2 h to synthesize the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP composite. As reference materials, Co0.85Se/NCP was prepared by directly calcining Co/NCP in the presence of Se powders under the same conditions. MoSe2/NCP was obtained after etching metal Co nanoparticles in Co/NCP by 2 M HCl for 4 h. 2.1.5 Synthesis of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S, Co0.85Se/NCP/S, and MoSe2/NCP/S Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP were grounded with sulfur in a mortar at a mass ratio of 3:7. The obtained material was heated in a tube furnace at 155 °C for 12 h, and then at 300 °C for 2 h under Ar atmosphere to remove surface sulfur. 2.2 Characterization The crystal structure was tested by X-ray diffraction (XRD). The morphology of the as-prepared samples (Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP) was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The surface composition and chemical state of the host materials were confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was used to measure the S content in the cathode from 50 to 400 °C under a 5 °C min−1 of heating rate in an N2 atmosphere. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements 2.3.1 LSBs assembly and measurements Cathodes were obtained by the following method. First, the active material (Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S, Co0.85Se/NCP/S, and MoSe2/NCP/S), Super P, and PVDF were mixed and ground at a ratio of 7:2:1. Then, NMP was added to the uniformly mixed powder to form a slurry, which was then coated on aluminum foil and vacuum-dried at 50 ℃ for 12 h. Finally, the slurry was cut into raw sheets with diameter of 12 mm (the active material S content is about 1 mg cm−2) to obtain the working electrode. Electrochemical measurements were conducted in standard 2032 coin-type cells. Li metal and Celgard 2400 PP were used as the anode electrode and separator, respectively. The electrolyte used was 1.0 M LiTFSI in DME and DOL (volume ratio of 1:1) with 2 wt% LiNO3 additive. For each coin cell, 20 µL of electrolyte was used. All cells underwent ageing to ensure sufficient electrolyte penetration before performing electrochemical tests. Galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) tests were performed at a current rate of 0.1–3 C with a voltage window of 1.7–2.8 V by using a Neware BTS4. Cycle voltammetry (CV) tests were studied at scan rates of 0.1–0.4 mV s−1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were also performed by the same electrochemical workstation and conducted over the frequency range of 0.01–105 Hz. All electrochemical experiments were performed at room temperature. 2.3.2 Synthesis of Li2S6 and Li2S8 solution and visual adsorption test A Li2S6 solution was prepared by dissolving S and Li2S (molar radio 5:1) in a mixed solvent of DOL/DME (V/V = 1:1) with vigorous stirring at 60 °C for 24 h. The preparation of the Li2S8 solution was like that of Li2S6, except for the molar ratio (7:1). For the visual adsorption test, 10 mg samples were added to the Li2S6 solution and soaked for 6 h. All the above operations were performed in an argon-filled glove box. 2.3.3 Synthesis of symmetrical cells and measurements Two identical electrodes were used as the working and counter electrodes with the mass loading of 1 mg cm−2, and 40 mL of electrolyte containing 0.5 M Li2S6 and 1 M LiTFSI dissolved in DOL/DME (V/V = 1:1) was added into the coin cells. The CV measurements of the symmetric cells were acquired over a voltage range of −1.0–1.0 V at various rates. 2.3.4 Measurements of the Li2S nucleation Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP electrodes served as cathode respectively. Lithium foil was used as the counter electrode. Celgard 2400 PP membrane served as the separator. 0.25 M Li2S8 with 1.0 M LiTFSI in tetra ethylene glycol dimethyl ether solution was used as the electrolyte. The cells were discharged at 2.05 V until the current dropped below 10−5. The Li2S nucleation capacity was calculated by the integral area of the curve via Faraday law. 2.4 Theoretical calculations All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP). The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional for the exchange-correlation term was used with the projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials and a cutoff energy of 400 eV. The convergence of energy and forces were set to 1×10−4 eV and 0.05 eV Å−1, respectively. The heterojunction model was constructed by the Co0.85Se and MoSe2. The lattice mismatch was no more than 3% and the vacuum layer was set as 15 Å to avoid the interactions between layers. The adsorption energy ΔE ad was calculated as Δ E a d = E ( s u r f + a d ) - E s u r f - E a d where E (surf+ad) is the energy of the lithium polysulfide (LiPS) adsorbed on the surface, E surf is the energy of the clean surface, and E ad is the energy of the free LiPS. The formula for calculating the Gibbs free is as follows Δ G S 8 - L i 2 S 8 : = E L i 2 S 8 - E S 8 - 2 E L i + Δ G L i 2 S 8 - L i 2 S 6 : = E L i 2 S 6 - E L i 2 S 8 + 0.25 E S 8 Δ G L i 2 S 6 - L i 2 S 4 : = E L i 2 S 4 - E L i 2 S 6 + 0.25 E S 8 Δ G L i 2 S 4 - L i 2 S 2 : = E L i 2 S 2 - E L i 2 S 4 + 0.25 E S 8 Δ G L i 2 S 2 - L i 2 S : = E L i 2 S - E L i 2 S 2 + 0.125 E S 8 3 Results and discussion Co0.85Se-MoSe2 catalysts supported on NCPs were produced from a ZIF, specifically, the cobalt-based ZIF-67, synthesized by a self-assembly process at room temperature [17] (Fig. 1 a, see the Experimental section for details). As shown in Fig. 1(b) and Fig. S1, the precursor ZIF-67 shows conventional dodecahedral particle morphology with a regular and smooth surface. Subsequently, ZIF-67 was pyrolyzed at 600 °C under Ar atmosphere for 2 h. At this temperature, Co is reduced and the organic molecules within the framework form a porous nitrogen-doped carbon structure that maintains the regular dodecahedron shape (Fig. 1c and Fig. S2a, b). Such obtained Co/NCP was loaded with molybdenum and phosphomolybdic acid via a hydrothermal reaction to obtain Co/NCP/PMo12 (Fig. S2b, c) [18]. Next, selenium powder was reacted with the Co and Mo cation nodes of the Co/NCP/PMo12 precursor at 700 °C to obtain the cobalt selenide/molybdenum selenide heterostructure supported on NCP. As displayed in Fig. 1(d), the final composite exhibits the uniform polyhedron morphology inherited from the ZIF-67 precursor, with an average size of 640 nm. The dodecahedrons present a polycrystalline structure (Fig. 1e). XRD analysis reveals the characteristic peaks of the hexagonal 2H MoSe2 (JCPDS PDF#29-0914) and the hexagonal close-packed structures NiAs-type Co0.85Se (JCPDS PDF#52-1008), as shown in Fig. 2 (a). No additional XRD peaks are observed. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) analysis shows two distinct crystallographic structures, one with a lattice spacing of 0.646 nm that could be interpreted as the (002) plane of 2H phase MoSe2, and the other with a lattice spacing of 0.268 nm that could be interpreted as the (101) plane of NiAs-type Co0.85Se (Fig. 1f). Co0.85Se is observed to grow with its [101] direction oriented X degrees with respect to the [002] crystallographic direction of the MoSe2 to minimize the interface stress (Fig. S3). Co0.85Se nanosheets are extended with an average size of around 55 nm, as observed from the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis (Fig. 1g). As a reference, Co0.85Se/NCP and MoSe2/NCP samples were produced following the same procedure but without introducing Mo in the former and by etching Co in the Co/NCP precursor in the latter (see the Experimental section for details). These reference samples also showed a dodecahedron geometry, with a diameter of approximately 500 nm (Fig. S4), the same crystallographic phases (Fig. 2a), and a similar size of the different domains (Figs. S5–S7). The degree of carbon graphitization was determined from the Raman spectra displaying the characteristic D (1350 cm−1) and G (1590 cm−1) bands, which correspond to disordered and sp 2 hybridized carbon bond-stretching vibrations, respectively (Fig. 2b and Fig. S8) [19]. The amorphous carbon provides abundant electrochemically active sites, while the graphitized carbon enhances conductivity and facilitates charge transfer. The intensity ratios of D and G bands (I D/I G) for Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP were very similar, being 1.00, 1.02, and 1.02, respectively. Furthermore, distinct Raman vibrations are evident in the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP and MoSe2/NCP samples, with 167.8, 237.4, and 286.2 cm−1 corresponding to the E1g, A1g, and E2g 1 modes of 2H MoSe2 [20]. Additionally, four prominent Raman peaks at 196.5, 466.2, 505.9, and 671.3 cm−1 can be attributed to the Ag, Eg, F2g 1, and A1g modes of NiAs-type Co0.85Se [21]. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas obtained from N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP were measured to be 206, 203, and 24 m2 g−1, respectively (Fig. 2c and Fig. S9). The low specific surface area of MoSe2/NCP limits the available sites for sulfur deposition, which can result in uneven sulfur distribution and lower sulfur utilization. In contrast, the relatively high specific surface area of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP and Co0.85Se/NCP can facilitate the accommodation and dispersion of sulfur, potentially contributing to the improved electrochemical performance [22]. XPS analysis confirmed the presence of Co, Mo, Se, C, and N elements on the surface of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP (Fig. S10). The high-resolution Co 2p XPS spectra for Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP and Co0.85Se/NCP (Fig. 2d) display two chemical states associated with divalent (Co2+) and trivalent (Co3+) cobalt [23]. The high-resolution Mo 3d XPS spectrum of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP displays three doublets assigned to Mo4+, Mo5+, and Mo6+. In comparison with MoSe2/NCP, the Mo 3d spectrum of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP positively shift by 0.5 eV, indicating a strong electronic interaction between Co0.85Se and MoSe2 (Fig. 2e). Two types of Se can be observed in the high-resolution Se 3d XPS. The two peaks between 52 and 57 eV belong to the Se 3d of Se anions within the metal selenide lattice, while the two peaks between 57 and 62 eV belong to the SeO x in the Co0.85Se-MoSe2 with some surface selenium oxidation. Compared with the pure Co0.85Se and MoSe2, a negative shift of Se 3d can be observed, and the deconvoluted peaks at 54.31 and 55.17 eV correspond to Se 3d 5/2 and Se 3d 3/2 of Co0.85Se-MoSe2, respectively. The possible oxidation states of selenium may be ascribed to the exposure of the sample to air [24] (Fig. 2f). The high-resolution C 1s XPS spectrum displays multiple peaks, assigned to C–C, C–O, and C=O bonds (Fig. S11a). Finally, the high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum displays three prominent peaks attributed to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N, respectively (Fig. S11b). DFT calculations showed the total density of states (TDOS) of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP at the Fermi level to be higher than that of Co0.85Se/NCP and MoSe2/NCP (Fig. 2g and h). These orbitals exhibit significant weights near the Fermi level. Their contribution is crucial as it indicates that Co plays a central role in modifying the electronic structure of the catalyst. The Co d orbitals hybridize with the neighboring Se p orbitals, thereby facilitating the charge transfer process across the heterointerface. In pure MoSe2, the Mo d and Se p orbitals define the band edges and maintain typical semiconductor properties. Upon heterostructure formation with Co0.85Se, the partial density of states (PDOS) shows shifts and new hybrid states, suggesting that Co doping shifts the Mo d band center and affects the catalytic active sites. By comparing the PDOS of the heterostructure with that of the pure phase, we can directly correlate specific electronic states with the enhanced catalytic performance observed experimentally. These detailed insights elucidate the role of individual atoms in facilitating electron transfer and bond activation during catalysis. The formation of the heterostructure results in a notable charge redistribution between the phases. As shown in Fig. S12, the differential charge distribution demonstrates that electron transfer occurs at the heterointerface between Co0.85Se and MoSe2. The charge redistribution at the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP interface and the electron transfer between different atoms were quantitatively determined by Bader charge analysis (Fig. 2i). This analysis showed a charge redistribution at the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP interface with MoSe2 gaining 0.90 electrons from Co0.85Se. The LiPS adsorption ability of the host materials was evaluated by immersing equal amounts of each composite in 5 mmol L−1 Li2S6 solution for 6 h. As observed from the optical images shown in Fig. 3 (a), after this time, the yellow-colored Co0.85Se/NCP and Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP solutions lost their color and turned colorless, while the MoSe2/NCP maintained the original yellow color. These data show the Co0.85Se to have a notable affinity for the LIPSs, which is enhanced by the formation of the heterostructure with MoSe2 [25]. After the adsorption test, the materials were collected, dried, and analyzed by XPS. Fig. 3(b–d) exhibits the high-resolution Co 2p, Mo 3d, and Se 3d XPS spectra of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP before and after the adsorption test. Compared with the original spectra, the entire XPS spectrum of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/Li2S6 shifted to higher values, particularly the Co 2p peaks, indicating a strong interaction of Li2S6 with surface Co, Mo, and Se sites. Fig. 3(e) shows the theoretical Li2S6 adsorption configuration on the surface of Co0.85Se-MoSe2, Co0.85Se, and MoSe2. The binding energy of Li2S6 on Co0.85Se-MoSe2 is significantly higher (−0.16 eV) than that on Co0.85Se (−0.11 eV) and MoSe2 (−0.12 eV), confirming the superior Li2S6 anchoring ability of Co0.85Se-MoSe2 compared to that of Co0.85Se and MoSe2. The optimized polysulfide adsorption configurations for the various catalysts are exhibited in Fig. 3(f), Figs. S13–S18, and Table S1. DFT results further show that the binding energy towards S8, the different LiPSs, and Li2S of Co0.85Se-MoSe2 is higher than that of Co0.85Se and MoSe2 at the six stages of the discharge process. Fig. 3(g) and Table S2 further show the bond lengths of Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S4, Li2S6, and Li2S8 to be longer on the Co0.85Se-MoSe2 than on Co0.85Se and MoSe2, which facilitates sulfur oxidation on the Co0.85Se-MoSe2 surface [26]. To assess the LiPS catalytic conversion capability of the different materials, symmetric cells were assembled using 0.5 M Li2S6 electrolyte. The cells were evaluated using CV at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 (Fig. 4 a). The Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP symmetric cell exhibited the highest current density and the largest oxidation peak area in comparison to Co0.85Se/NCP and MoSe2/NCP cells. Notably, the CV curves recorded in Li2S6-free electrolyte showed a minimal current response, highlighting that the lithiation/delithiation reaction dominated the current under these conditions. EIS analysis of the symmetric cells showed that the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP exhibits the smallest charge transfer resistance, 14.4 Ω, during the sulfur redox reaction (SRR) process, much lower than that of Co0.85Se/NCP being 17.6 Ω and that of MoSe2/NCP being 21.5 Ω (Fig. 4b and Fig. S19). The kinetics of Li2S nucleation and growth on the surfaces of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, MoSe2/NCP, and Co0.85Se/NCP was investigated to evaluate the catalytic efficiency of these sulfur hosts [27]. In comparison to MoSe2/NCP and Co0.85Se/NCP, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP cathode exhibited the earliest nucleation onset, the highest current response, and the largest capacity during the potentiation test at 2.05 V (Fig. 4c and Table S3). Based on Faraday's law (Q = It, where Q is capacity, I is current, and t is time), the capacity of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP reached 238 mAh g−1, outperforming MoSe2/NCP (198 mAh g−1) and Co0.85Se/NCP (200 mAh g−1). These results underscore the effectiveness of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP electrode in reducing the overpotential of the Li-S redox reaction, suppressing the polysulfide shuttle effect and accelerating Li2S nucleation. To study the electrochemical performance of the different materials as sulfur hosts, they were infiltrated with yielding S to obtain Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S, Co0.85Se/NCP/S, and MoSe2/NCP/S composites. XRD characterization shows that the crystalline S phase exists in such composites and TGA reveals the sulfur content in Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S Co0.85Se/NCP/S, and MoSe2/NCP/S to be 69.39%, 67.82%, and 69.48% respectively (Fig. S20). As shown in Fig. 4(d) and Fig. S21, the LiPS reduction process on Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S showed the lowest overpotential, implying the lowest reduction energy barrier. The two cathodic peaks correspond to the stepwise reduction of S8 into long-chain LiPSs (Li2S x , 4 < x < 8) and their subsequent transformation into insoluble products, Li2S2 and Li2S [28]. The Tafel analysis of the LiPS reduction kinetics (Fig. 4e and Fig. S22a) shows that Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S promotes the fastest reaction with the lowest Tafel slopes of 24.8 and 71.9 mV dec−1, well below those of Co0.85Se/NCP/S (39.9 and 74.6 mV dec−1) and MoSe2/NCP (45.9 and 126.0 mV dec−1). The anodic peak reflects the reverse, multi-step oxidation process, where short-chain sulfides are oxidized back to LiPS and eventually reconverted to sulfur. During the oxidation process, Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes also presented the lowest Tafel slope of 50.6 mV dec−1, compared to Co0.85Se/NCP/S (55.8 mV dec−1) and MoSe2/NCP/S (82.6 mV dec−1) (Fig. S22b). DFT calculations were further used to determine the evolution of the Gibbs free energy during the S reduction pathway for the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se/NCP, and MoSe2/NCP cathodes. The models and free energy distribution of polysulfide intermediates are shown in Fig. 4(f). The lithiation pathway from S8 to Li2S includes several steps. The first step involves the reduction of S8 with two Li+ to form Li2S8, which evolves to Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2, and lastly Li2S as the final product [29]. The conversion of Li2S4 to Li2S2 and Li2S2 to Li2S is the rate-limiting steps [30]. The Gibbs free energy changes associated with the production of Li2S2 and Li2S on the surface of Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP are 0.87 and 0.52 eV, respectively, well below the energy barriers calculated for Co0.85Se/NCP (1.03 and 0.80 eV) and MoSe2/NCP (1.13 and 1.01 eV). The breaking of S–S bonds on the surfaces of different host materials was further analyzed using DFT calculations (Fig. 4g) [31]. These calculations reveal that the bonding environment of adsorbed sulfur species is significantly altered on the catalyst surface, particularly in the electron density of bonding (π) and antibonding (π*) states near the Fermi level. Compared to Co0.85Se/NCP and MoSe2/NCP, Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP shows an upward shift of its energy states, reducing the stability of the S–S bonds. This electronic shift facilitates the dissociation of the S–S bond, thereby accelerating the kinetics of the Li-S redox reactions. This redistribution specifically affects the S–S bond, weakening the stability of the S–S bonds relative to the more “inert” configuration observed in the individual pure materials. This can be attributed to the synergistic effects of the heterointerface, where the electronic states of Co and Mo contribute to shifting the energy levels of the sulfur orbitals. This catalytic enhancement in the heterostructure is key to improving the overall performance of LSBs. Coin cells were assembled using the sulfur cathode, a lithium foil anode, and a solution of DOL and DME in a 1:1 vol ratio comprising 1.0 M LiTFSI and 1 wt% LiNO3 as the electrolyte (see the Suppording Information for details). Fig. 5 (a) presents GCD curves of the various cathode materials (Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S, Co0.85Se/NCP/S, and MoSe2/NCP/S) at a current rate of 0.1 C (1 C = 1.675 A g−1). As typically observed in LSBs, two distinct voltage plateaus appear during the discharge process. The first plateau, between 2.4 and 2.1 V, corresponds to the conversion of S8 to long-chain LiPSs (S8 to Li2S4) [32]. The second plateau, within the 2.1–1.7 V window, is associated with the liquid-solid conversion of soluble LiPS to insoluble Li2S2 (Li2S4 to Li2S2) and the solid-solid conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S [33]. Among the different sulfur cathodes tested, Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S exhibits the highest initial specific capacity (1279 mAh g−1), which surpasses Co0.85Se/NCP (1180 mAh g−1) and MoSe2/NCP (1073 mAh g−1). The voltage difference ΔE between the oxidation plateau and the second reduction plateau is often used as a measure of the polarization potential in Li-S reactions (Fig. 5b) [34]. The polarization voltage of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode (158 mV) is significantly lower than that of Co0.85Se/NCP/S (197 mV) and MoSe2/NCP/S (220 mV). Another key metric for evaluating the catalytic activity of host materials for LiPS conversion is the capacity ratio of the first discharge plateau (Q1) to the second discharge plateau (Q2) [35]. During the S8 lithiation process, the first plateau involves 4 electrons and the second plateau involves 12 electrons, resulting in a theoretical Q2/Q1 ratio of 3. In practice, the ratio is typically lower due to the dissolution of polysulfides and the incomplete reduction of Li2S4 to Li2S on the second discharge plateau [36]. This ratio reflects the extent of the reduction reaction completion and is directly related to the catalytic ability and capacity of the host material to inhibit the shuttle effect. Fig. 5(b) shows that the Q2/Q1 ratio for Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S is 2.46, which is significantly higher than that of Co0.85Se/NCP/S (2.28) and MoSe2/NCP/S (2.21). As the current rate increases from 0.1 to 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 C, the specific capacity of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S cathode decreases from 1516 to 1134, 1017, 880, 772, and 666 mAh g−1, respectively (Fig. 5c and Fig. S23). Compared with other sulfur cathodes, Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S exhibits the highest initial specific capacitance (1516 mAh g−1), well above that of Co0.85Se/NCP/S (1259 mAh g−1), MoSe2/NCP/S (1218 mAh g−1), and most previously reported cathodes (Fig. S24 and Table S4) [37–42]. Notably, a clear voltage plateau is still observed at 3 C, indicating that the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP host efficiently catalyzes LiPS conversion. Upon returning to 0.2 C, the specific capacity of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode recovers to 1025 mAh g−1, demonstrating notable stability after high-rate charge/discharge cycles. This performance exceeds that of all other electrodes, highlighting the significant catalytic role of the heterostructured material. The rate performance curves for the sulfur cathodes are shown in Fig. 5(d and e). As expected, the specific capacities decrease with increasing current rate. However, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode maintains the highest specific capacity across all rates, further demonstrating that the formation of the heterostructure significantly promotes polysulfide adsorption and charge transfer. Fig. 5(f) illustrates the CV curves of different batteries at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. All curves show two cathodic peaks (C1 and C2) and one anodic peak (A), which correlate with the charge/discharge plateaus. The two cathodic peaks account for the reduction of sulfur to polysulfides (S8/Li2S8 → Li2S6/Li2S4), followed by the reduction to Li2S2/Li2S (Li2S6/Li2S4 → Li2S2/Li2S). The anodic peak corresponds to the oxidation of polysulfides back to sulfur (Li2S2/Li2S → Li2S8/S8). Among all cathode materials, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode exhibits the highest current density, reflecting the most efficient polysulfide conversion and the lowest polarization voltage. Additionally, the cathodic peak for the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode shifts slightly to a higher potential and shows a larger current density, indicating an enhanced conversion rate of LiPS to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S. Furthermore, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S-based battery displays the highest cathode peak onset potential and the lowest anode peak onset potential (Fig. 5g and Fig. S25), confirming that the presence of the heterostructure accelerates the redox reaction kinetics, further improving overall battery performance. The lithium-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li+) was qualitatively evaluated through CV tests at varying scan rates (0.1–0.4 mV s−1) within the voltage range of 1.7–2.8 V. As shown in Fig. 5(h) and Fig. S26, the peak current increased with the scan rate, while the shape of the curves remained consistent, indicating good electrochemical stability. A linear relationship was observed between the peak current (I p) for both reduction and oxidation processes and the square root of the scan rate (v), as shown in Fig. 5(i) and Fig. S27, suggesting a diffusion-limited process. D Li+ was subsequently calculated using the Randles-Sevcik equation [43]. (1) I p = 2.69 × 10 5 × n 1.5 × A × D L i + 0.5 × C L i + × v 0.5 where n and A are the charge number and charge geometry area. As displayed in Fig. 5(j), D Li+ on the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode was 4.28 × 10−7, 2.01 × 10−7, and 2.21 × 10−7 cm2 s−1, as calculated from A, C1, and C2 peaks, respectively. These D Li+ values were significantly higher than those of the Co0.85Se/NCP/S and MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes. We suggest that the higher D Li+ obtained for the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode is related to the increased catalytic activity of LiPS conversion, which prevents LiPS from dissolving in large quantities and thus the formation of a high-viscosity electrolyte and post-insulation layers. Galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) profiles were obtained at 0.1 C to further investigate the polysulfides redox kinetics with Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S, Co0.85Se/NCP/S, and MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes during discharge/charge (Fig. 5k and Fig. S28) [44]. The corresponding internal reaction resistance ΔR internal was calculated according to the following equation [45]. (2) Δ R i n t e r n a l Ω = Δ V Q O C V - C C V I a p p l i e d where ΔV QOCV-CCV is the voltage difference between the quasi-open-circuit-voltage (QOCV) and closed-circuit voltage (CCV) points and I applied is the applied current. As illustrated in Fig. 5(l), the results demonstrate that Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S exhibits significantly lower internal resistance than Co0.85Se/NCP/S and MoSe2/NCP/S during the both discharge and charging processes. This reduction in internal resistance is particularly notable at the Li2S nucleation and activation sites, indicating a more efficient conversion process from Li2S2 to Li2S. This suggests that the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP electrode facilitates the enhanced charge transfer and ion diffusion, thereby improving the overall kinetics of the sulfur redox reactions. To assess the cycling stability of LSB with different cathodes, charge/discharge tests were conducted over 100 cycles at a constant current of 0.5 C (Fig. 6 a). The Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode demonstrated an initial discharge capacity of 978 mAh g−1 and retained 933 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles. This performance significantly surpasses that of Co0.85Se/NCP/S (674 mAh g−1, with a capacity retention of 80.5%) and MoSe2/NCP/S (573 mAh g−1, with a capacity retention of 81.8%), underscoring the superior cycling stability of the heterostructure cathode. The corresponding GCD profiles for the 1st and 100th cycle at 0.5 C are shown in Fig. S29, where all discharge curves exhibit the two characteristic plateaus and the charge curves display the typical single plateau. In the EIS spectra, the semicircle in the high-frequency region represents the charge transfer resistance, while the straight line in the low-frequency region corresponds to the diffusion resistance (Fig. S30). As depicted in Fig. 6(b) and Fig. S31(a), the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode exhibits lower charge transfer and diffusion resistance (76.2 Ω) compared to Co0.85Se/NCP/S (90.8 Ω) and MoSe2/NCP/S (128.0 Ω), indicating the improved redox kinetics. After cycling, an additional semicircle appears in the high-frequency region (Fig. 6c and Fig. S31b), which is attributed to the formation of the solid Li2S/Li2S2 passivation layer. Moreover, the resistance significantly decreases after cycling due to the progressive electrolyte infiltration into the electrode and the redispersion of active sulfur species on the electrode surface, further enhancing overall performance. The long-term cycling performances of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S, Co0.85Se/NCP/S, and MoSe2/NCP/S cells were further investigated at a higher current density of 1.0 C. Notably, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrode exhibited an initial capacity of 829 mAh g−1, which decreased to 644 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles, resulting in a capacity loss of 0.044% per cycle. In contrast, the Co0.85Se/NCP/S and MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes exhibited lower specific capacities of 758 and 565 mAh g−1, corresponding to higher capacity decays of 0.080% and 0.097% per cycle, respectively (Fig. 6d). These results highlight the remarkable redox reaction kinetics of the heterostructured electrode. As shown in Fig. S32, all discharge curves corresponding to the 1st and the 500th cycle at 1 C present the two typical plateaus, and all charge curves show the usual single plateau. After 200 cycles at 1 C, the cycled coin-type cells were disassembled and analyzed. A stark contrast in the color of different battery separators was observed (Fig. S33). In contrast to the Co0.85Se/NCP/S and MoSe2/NCP/S separators, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S separator appeared nearly transparent, indicating a superior ability of the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP host to capture polysulfides. Besides, significant cracks and corrosion were observed on the lithium anode surfaces of the Co0.85Se/NCP/S and MoSe2/NCP/S coin cells. In contrast, the lithium foil retrieved from the recycled Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S coin cells exhibited a smooth surface with a low sulfur signal, as evidenced by SEM and EDX analysis (Figs. S34–S36). Finally, we performed SEM analysis (Fig. S37) on the cycled cathode material. The SEM images demonstrate that the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S structure predominantly retains the integrity without significant collapse after cycling. In contrast, the Co0.85Se/NCP/S and MoSe2/NCP/S structures experienced substantial collapse during the charge-discharge cycles, primarily attributed to volume expansion. To assess the practical application potential of LSBs based on Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes, cells were assembled using higher sulfur loadings. Long-term cycling was conducted at a sulfur loading of 3.0 mg cm−2 and a current density of 0.2 C, as depicted in Fig. 6(e). At electrolyte-to-sulfur (E/S) ratios of 13.3 and 6.7 μL mg−1, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S heterostructure maintained specific capacities of approximately 547 and 432 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles, with capacity retentions of around 67.4% and 56.2%, respectively. The corresponding GCD curves (Fig. 6f) illustrate a widening voltage gap with the decreased electrolyte volume, attributed to the increased polarization resulting from impaired ion transport in high-viscosity electrolytes. Finally, as shown in Fig. 6(g), an light emitting diode (LED) (voltage: 2–2.2 V) strip was powered with two Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S-based coin cells to showcase its applicability. Overall, Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP heterointerface shortens the charge transfer path and improves electron transfer efficiency, thereby accelerating reaction kinetics and enhancing catalytic performance (Fig. 6h). Thereby, this catalyst demonstrates excellent performance in boosting electron transfer and reaction kinetics, ultimately achieving high performance and long-term stability in LSBs. 4 Conclusions In summary, a Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP composite was synthesized and demonstrated to provide exceptional performance as a sulfur host in LSB cathodes. As shown by both DFT calculations and experimental results, the catalytic heterostructure increases electron transfer efficiency and accelerates the polysulfide redox kinetics in LSBs. Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP not only exhibits excellent electrocatalytic performance, rate capability, and cycling stability, but also shows outstanding cycling stability even under high sulfur loading and dilute electrolyte conditions. Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes provides an initial capacity of 1516 mAh g−1 and a capacity decay rate of only 0.044% per cycle at 1 C during the 500 cycles. Overall, this work provides an effective strategy for developing high-performance LSBs by leveraging the synergistic effects of the NiAs-type/2H-phase heterostructure. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are a promising candidate for next-generation energy storage solutions. However, challenges such as the shuttling effect and sluggish Li-S reaction kinetics of lithium polysulfides hinder their practical application. In this work, we present a mixed-phase heterostructure comprising Co0.85Se and MoSe2, supported on nitrogen-doped carbon polyhedrons (NCP), as an effective sulfur host in the LSB cathode. Through a combination of theoretical calculations and experimental validation, we demonstrate that the Co0.85Se-MoSe2 heterointerface significantly enhances electron transfer efficiency, thereby boosting the overall reaction kinetics of the sulfur cathode. As a result, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes exhibit initial specific capacities exceeding 1500 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and retain 666 mAh g−1 at 3 C, with a capacity fade rate of 0.044% per cycle over 500 cycles at 1.0 C. Notably, even at a high sulfur loading of 3 mg cm−2 and a reduced electrolyte volume of 6.7 μL mgS −1, the Co0.85Se-MoSe2/NCP/S electrodes maintain a capacity of 432 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C.
